fields.description:
Currently, the DefaultAuthenticator sets the login cookie with a path of /. This means the cookie:

* conflicts with other seraph-enabled apps on the same server (CONF-440), 
* is made available to other apps running on the same server with different context roots (possible security issue)

Eric

fields.description:
Not sure if this is helpful, but here is what I have discovered in attempting to use Seraph:
1) LoginFilter/ServletFilter on website example for what goes in web.xml need this as the package: com.atlassian.seraph.filter.
2) Not security-config but seraph-config.xml.
3) By default I cut'n'pasted the config file.  So I got the line:
com.atlassian.myapp.setup.MyAppSecurityController
Would it be worth providing a dummy security controller that just says "I'm here, and security is on!" so that every user doesn't hit this error?  Maybe a NoOpSecurityController..  Or even one that flipped security on and off by passing in a paramter as part of a request?  Just trying to think of all the newbie things I ran into!
4) I think in ServiceConfig is a bug..  It is not properly checking for a bug.  Should be:

if (serviceClazz == null || ("".equals(serviceClazz))){
                    throw new ConfigurationException("Service element with bad class attribute");
                }

If you like, I can submit a seperate JIRA with a unit test etc..

I wanted to try and integrate the Fulcrum Security backend.  However, I can't build because I can't find the jars:

I could probably build from cvs the dated ones, but not the Dev one!

Would it be possible to put them in a Seraph repository?  Put a line like this in the project.properties:
maven.repo.remote=http://hqitapp01/docs/repository,http://www.ibiblio.org/maven/

Sincerely,
Eric Pugh

fields.description:
I believe that this conditional is incorrect on line 185 in com.atlassian.seraph.config.SecurityConfig.

Currently it is:
  if (serviceClazz != null && !"".equals(serviceClazz))

If this evaluates to false then further down on line 191 a ClassNotFoundException will be thrown.

It should probably be:
  if (serviceClazz != null && "".equals(serviceClazz))

Maybe I am completely wrong and missing something.

fields.description:
The filter configuration documentation located at http://opensource.atlassian.com/seraph/configuration.html has the incorrect package name for the LoginFilter and the SecurityFilter.

Currently they are listed as follows:
  com.atlassian.core.security.LoginFilter
  com.atlassian.core.security.SecurityFilter

They should be:
  com.atlassian.seraph.filter.LoginFilter
  com.atlassian.seraph.filter.SecurityFilter

fields.description:
We'd like to establish a trusted chain. However, currently the bitbucket-server image is unsigned.
{code:java}
% docker trust inspect atlassian/bitbucket-server
[]
No signatures or cannot access atlassian/bitbucket-server
{code}
The main security concern is to be sure the image pulled from dockerhub are signed by Atlassian by the private key which is stored security on the vendor side.

If Atlassian can sign the images before push them to the dockerhub, we can pull they security, and in case the image doesn't have a valid signature we drop it.
fields.summary: Sign Atlassian images on dockerhub

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Admin and Database password validation is broken when configuring a Confluence deployment via the Azure deployment UI.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

*Supply database password:*
 When providing a database password ( {{Zh*wMRrPZJvcYt8q}} ) that conforms to the password rules:
{code:java}
between 8 and 16 characters long, and must contain at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, one number (0-9), and one non-alphanumeric character (!, $, #, %, etc.).
{code}
we are told that it is not valid...

!image-2021-06-18-10-51-57-019.png|width=1366,height=656!

It turns out that there is mismatch between password tooltip and the passwords regex itself:
 [https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/atlassian-azure-deployment/src/38e87d752181586a32e48ca5fe6761913e4a8359/confluence/createUiDefinition.json#lines-632]

{{"regex": "^(?=.*[A-Z])(?=.*[!@#$%])(?=.*[0-9])(?=.*[a-z]).\{12,16}$"}}

This mismatch is causing confusion here.

 

*Supply admin password*
 The admin password validation is broken. When providing the password {{Zh*wMRrPZJv}} we are told that the password must be at least 5 chars long. When a password of 5 chars is supplied we are told the same thing. Details of the password format are not provided either.

[!image-2021-06-18-10-52-22-527.png|width=1204,height=773!|https://bulldog.internal.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/542724/542724_screenshot-3.png]

Looking at the {{createUiDefinition.json}} we see that the password validation simply comprises a regex ensuring a string length between 12 and 17 chars is provided:

[https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/atlassian-azure-deployment/src/38e87d752181586a32e48ca5fe6761913e4a8359/confluence/createUiDefinition.json#lines-82]

Sure enough if a string comprising any chars that is between 12 and 16 chars in length is supplied validation passes.

The tooltip for this is wrong too ( {{This password must be a minimum of 5 characters long.}} ) , which explains the confusion through the UI:
 [https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/atlassian-azure-deployment/src/38e87d752181586a32e48ca5fe6761913e4a8359/confluence/createUiDefinition.json#lines-83]
h3. Actual Results

Password tooltip and password regex do not match which is causing confusion
h3. Expected Results

Password tooltip conforms to the password regex. 
h3. Workaround
 * For the admin passwords provide a string that is between 12 and 16 characters in length
 * For the database passwords provide a string that is between 12 and 16 characters in length and comprises an UPPERCASE and lowecase letter, an integer and one of the following characters !@#$%
fields.summary: Azure Confluence config password tooltip validation broken

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The [official Docker image|https://hub.docker.com/r/atlassian/confluence-server/] for Confluence contains a server.xml based on Jira.

Instead, we need to embed the default server.xml that is created from a brand new installation.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a new Confluence container, using the command from Docker Hub:
{code:java}
docker run -v /data/your-confluence-home:/var/atlassian/application-data/confluence --name="confluence" -d -p 8090:8090 -p 8091:8091 atlassian/confluence
{code}
 # Log into the container and check the file {{server.xml}}

h3. Expected Results

The image should contain the default server.xml for new Confluence installations. For example, the parameter *protocol* is *org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11NioProtocol*
{code:xml|title=Default Confluence server.xml}
<Server port="8000" shutdown="SHUTDOWN" debug="0">
    <Service name="Tomcat-Standalone">
        <!--
         ==============================================================================================================
         DEFAULT - Direct connector with no proxy, for unproxied HTTP access to Confluence.

         If using a http/https proxy, comment out this connector.
         ==============================================================================================================
        -->
        <Connector port="8090" connectionTimeout="20000" redirectPort="8443"
                   maxThreads="48" minSpareThreads="10"
                   enableLookups="false" acceptCount="10" debug="0" URIEncoding="UTF-8"
                   protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11NioProtocol"/>
        <!--
         ==============================================================================================================
         HTTP - Proxying Confluence via Apache or Nginx over HTTP

         If you're proxying traffic to Confluence over HTTP, uncomment the connector below and comment out the others.
         Make sure you provide the right information for proxyName and proxyPort.

         For more information see:
            Apache - https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/4xQLM
            nginx  - https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/TgSvEg

         ==============================================================================================================
        -->

        <!--
        <Connector port="8090" connectionTimeout="20000" redirectPort="8443"
                   maxThreads="48" minSpareThreads="10"
                   enableLookups="false" acceptCount="10" debug="0" URIEncoding="UTF-8"
                   protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11NioProtocol"
                   scheme="http" proxyName="<subdomain>.<domain>.com" proxyPort="80"/>
        -->

        <!--
         ==============================================================================================================
         HTTPS - Direct connector with no proxy, for unproxied HTTPS access to Confluence.

         For more info see https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/s3UC
         ==============================================================================================================
        -->

        <!--
        <Connector port="8443" maxHttpHeaderSize="8192"
                   maxThreads="150" minSpareThreads="25"
                   protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11Nio2Protocol"
                   enableLookups="false" disableUploadTimeout="true"
                   acceptCount="100" scheme="https" secure="true"
                   clientAuth="false" sslProtocol="TLSv1.2" sslEnabledProtocols="TLSv1.2" SSLEnabled="true"
                   URIEncoding="UTF-8" keystorePass="<MY_CERTIFICATE_PASSWORD>"/>
        -->

        <!--
         ==============================================================================================================
         HTTPS - Proxying Confluence via Apache or Nginx over HTTPS

         If you're proxying traffic to Confluence over HTTPS, uncomment the connector below and comment out the others.
         Make sure you provide the right information for proxyName and proxyPort.

         For more information see:
            Apache - https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/PTT3MQ
            nginx  - https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/cNIvMw
         ==============================================================================================================
        -->

        <!--
        <Connector port="8090" connectionTimeout="20000" redirectPort="8443"
                   maxThreads="48" minSpareThreads="10"
                   enableLookups="false" acceptCount="10" debug="0" URIEncoding="UTF-8"
                   protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11NioProtocol"
                   scheme="https" secure="true" proxyName="<subdomain>.<domain>.com" proxyPort="443"/>
        -->

        <Engine name="Standalone" defaultHost="localhost" debug="0">
            <Host name="localhost" debug="0" appBase="webapps" unpackWARs="true" autoDeploy="false" startStopThreads="4">
                <Context path="" docBase="../confluence" debug="0" reloadable="false" useHttpOnly="true">
                    <!-- Logging configuration for Confluence is specified in confluence/WEB-INF/classes/log4j.properties -->
                    <Manager pathname=""/>
                    <Valve className="org.apache.catalina.valves.StuckThreadDetectionValve" threshold="60"/>

                    <!-- http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-9.0-doc/config/valve.html#Access_Log_Valve -->
                    <Valve className="org.apache.catalina.valves.AccessLogValve"
                           directory="logs"
                           maxDays="30"
                           pattern="%t %{X-AUSERNAME}o %I %h %r %s %Dms %b %{Referer}i %{User-Agent}i"
                           prefix="conf_access_log"
                           requestAttributesEnabled="true"
                           rotatable="true"
                           suffix=".log"
                    />

                    <!-- http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-9.0-doc/config/valve.html#Remote_IP_Valve -->
                    <Valve className="org.apache.catalina.valves.RemoteIpValve" />
                </Context>

                <Context path="${confluence.context.path}/synchrony-proxy" docBase="../synchrony-proxy" debug="0"
                         reloadable="false" useHttpOnly="true">
                    <Valve className="org.apache.catalina.valves.StuckThreadDetectionValve" threshold="60"/>
                </Context>
            </Host>
        </Engine>
    </Service>
</Server>
{code}
h3. Actual Results

The *server.xml* is created based on Jira's default file. The *protocol* is HTTP/1.1 and we also have some parameters that don't make sense to Confluence, like relaxedPathChars and relaxedQueryChars.
{code:xml|title=Current server.xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

<Server port="8000"
        shutdown="SHUTDOWN">

  <Listener className="org.apache.catalina.startup.VersionLoggerListener"/>
  <Listener className="org.apache.catalina.core.AprLifecycleListener"
            SSLEngine="on"/>
  <Listener className="org.apache.catalina.core.JreMemoryLeakPreventionListener"/>
  <Listener className="org.apache.catalina.mbeans.GlobalResourcesLifecycleListener"/>
  <Listener className="org.apache.catalina.core.ThreadLocalLeakPreventionListener"/>

  <Service name="Catalina">

    <Connector port="8090"
               maxThreads="100"
               minSpareThreads="10"
               connectionTimeout="20000"
               enableLookups="false"
               protocol="HTTP/1.1"
               redirectPort="8443"
               acceptCount="10"
               secure="false"
               scheme="http"
               proxyName=""
               proxyPort=""

               relaxedPathChars="[]|"
               relaxedQueryChars="[]|{}^\`"<>"
               bindOnInit="false"
               maxHttpHeaderSize="8192"
               useBodyEncodingForURI="true"
               disableUploadTimeout="true" />

    <Engine name="Standalone"
            defaultHost="localhost"
            debug="0">
      <Host name="localhost"
            debug="0"
            appBase="webapps"
            unpackWARs="true"
            autoDeploy="false"
            startStopThreads="4">
        <Context path=""
                 docBase="../confluence"
                 debug="0"
                 reloadable="false"
                 useHttpOnly="true">
          <!-- Logging configuration for Confluence is specified in confluence/WEB-INF/classes/log4j.properties -->
          <Manager pathname=""/>
          <Valve className="org.apache.catalina.valves.StuckThreadDetectionValve"
                 threshold="60"/>
        
        </Context>

        <Context path="${confluence.context.path}/synchrony-proxy"
                 docBase="../synchrony-proxy"
                 debug="0"
                 reloadable="false"
                 useHttpOnly="true">
          <Valve className="org.apache.catalina.valves.StuckThreadDetectionValve"
                 threshold="60"/>
        </Context>
      </Host>
    </Engine>
  </Service>
</Server>
{code}
h3. Workaround

Manually update the server.xml.j2 file to adjust it and restart the Confluence container.
fields.summary: Confluence Docker image contains a server.xml based on Jira

fields.description:
In the Bitbucket quickstart template for deployment on AWS, the default value of HomeDeleteOnTermination is true: [https://github.com/aws-quickstart/quickstart-atlassian-bitbucket/blob/b8863614d8653b10aeddba8f36de795f8353e565/templates/quickstart-bitbucket-dc.template.yaml#L511-L516]



In the event an NFS server is accidentally terminated, this causes full data loss of the source code on Bitbucket server. We had a production incident where exactly that happened and caused us to restore from backup.
fields.summary: Set default value of HomeDeleteOnTermination to false

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Since NFS fixer pod has a pre-install hook annotation, Helm processes this template before it looks at others. This pod uses a PVC which Helm can create for you but it happens only after pre-install things are completed. It results in nfs fixer pod just sitting there in a pending state since it share-home PVC is never created.

GitHub issue: [https://github.com/atlassian-labs/data-center-helm-charts/issues/75]
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Deploy any DC product with Helm with

 

{\{ --set volumes.sharedHome.persistentVolumeClaim.create=true }}
 {{--set volumes.sharedHome.nfsPermissionFixer.enabled=true}}
h3. Expected Results

NFS fixer pod does its job and the installation continues
h3. Actual Results

NFS fixer pod stuck in a pending state because of a missing PVC:
{noformat}
NAME                        READY   STATUS    RESTARTS   AGE
bitbucket-nfs-fixer-jvx5n   0/1     Pending   0          4m51s
postgres-postgresql-0       1/1     Running   0          14m

Events:
  Type     Reason            Age    From               Message
  ----     ------            ----   ----               -------
  Warning  FailedScheduling  6m54s  default-scheduler  persistentvolumeclaim "bitbucket-shared-home" not found
  Warning  FailedScheduling  5m30s  default-scheduler  persistentvolumeclaim "bitbucket-shared-home" not found
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Removing pre-install hook annotation is a workaround but very unreliable since the pod can start after Jira/Connie/BBDC starts writing to share home.
fields.summary: DC Helm Charts: NFS Fixer pod is stuck in pending state

fields.description:
Disable TLS 1.0, TLS 1.1 on the AWS loadbalancer. 

The CloudFormation templates enable TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 even though these are no longer considered secure. 

Please disable these by default or allow us to specify our own TLS options and ciphers.
fields.summary: Disable old TLS protocols

fields.description: Atlassian Cloud formation templates don't provide an option of Encryption of EFS file shares during deployment.
fields.summary: Provide an option for Encryption for EFS fileshares in the Atlassian CloudFormation templates

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Users cannot set server time zone when they are installing or migrating Jira via CloudFormation template
h3. Expected Results

Users should be able to choose the server TZ when creating Jira environments via the CloudFormation template
h3. Actual Results

The server starts with UTC TZ. This impacts users, especially during the migration. If the source server (and the data) is not in the UTC time zone, then some parts of the data from today are shown on the previous or on the next day.
h3. Workaround

To change server TZ manually
fields.summary: Users can set time zone of the stack during Jira installation via CloudFormation Template

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Cannot upgrade Jira via cloud formation template from 8.13.2 to 8.13.3 or 8.15.0 when we select *Sofware* as Jira Product
h3. Steps to Reproduce
If we select *Sofware* as Jira Product, the installation/upgrade is done but Jira does not start.
!Screenshot 2021-02-05 at 11.06.30.png!

h3. Expected Results
Jira should start successfully.
h3. Actual Results
The server (stack) starts successfully and Jira installation is done but Jira doesn't start automatically.

h3. Workaround
SSH to stack and start Jira manually
fields.summary: Jira SW & SD does not start if it's installed via CloudFormation Template with SOFTWARE Jira Product option

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Cannot upgrade Jira via cloud formation template from 8.13.2 to 8.13.3 or 8.15.0 when we select *ALL* as Jira Product
h3. Steps to Reproduce
When we select "ALL" along with Jira version *8.15.0* in the Cloudformation template are used, the ansible task [*product_install: Get the JSD build version info*] fails, and the playbook execution breaks. This leaves us with a totally unconfigured broken node.
 !Screenshot 2021-02-05 at 11.09.39.png|thumbnail!
h3. Expected Results
Upgrade or installation needs to finish successfully without any manual actions
h3. Actual Results
It seems the URL we're going to does not provide the valid results we're expecting back to determine the compatible ServiceDesk/ServiceManagement version:
{code:java}
https://marketplace.atlassian.com/rest/2/products/key/jira-servicedesk/versions/latest/?application=jira&applicationBuild=815000
{code}
Response:
{code:java}
{"errors":[{"message":"applicationBuild: Not a valid build number for Jira"}]}
https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/dc-deployments-automation/src/master/roles/product_install/tasks/jira-servicedesk_as_obr.yml
{code}
(i) Just guessing here that it has to do with the product name change from ServiceDesk to ServiceManagement.
h3. Workaround
* Use *Software* option on the stack details page
* Start Jira manually
* Install Service Desk
fields.summary: Jira SW & SD cannot be installed via CloudFormation Template with ALL Jira Product option

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The "deploy CDN for internal" template, AtlassianCDNInternal.template.yaml, located at [https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/atlassian-aws-deployment/src/master/templates/cdn/AtlassianCDNInternal.template.yaml], and linked from [https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/configure-your-cdn-for-jira-data-center-974378841.html], is not working for port 443 / SSL.
 * The template deploys the load balancer on port 80
 * When entering the load balancer URL using HTTPS on the application CDN configuration, the connection cannot be made as the load balancer is not listening on SSL/443

 
 The readme for “CloudFront CDN for private deployments” in templates/cdn/README-cdnprivate.md says that

 

{quote}
After deploying your CloudFront CDN stack, open its Stack Details page. From there, check the Outputs tab and note the value of "LoadBalancerURL"; this is your "CDN URL". 
 But the LoadBalancerListener is deployed using HTTP on port 80 and not HTTPS on 443
 LoadBalancerListener:
 Type: AWS::ElasticLoadBalancingV2::Listener
 Properties:
 DefaultActions:
 - Type: forward
 TargetGroupArn: !Ref MainTargetGroup
 LoadBalancerArn: !Ref LoadBalancer
 Port: 80
 Protocol: HTTP
{quote}

h3. Steps to Reproduce

 # Deploy the template
 # Once the application is up, try to configure the CDN URL on the application to be the LoadBalancerURL

h3. Expected Results

We are able to connect to the CDN on 443
h3. Actual Results

We are not able to connect, as the application has a TLS/443 requirement, which the template seems not to fulfil.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: AtlassianCDNInternal.template.yaml is not working with TLS, which is required by the app for CDN

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to use Jira DC Quick Start templates with CDN which is available for Jira DC. As it stands, the solution does not appear to allow for CDN in the current Quick Start template. Can we add this to the templates?
fields.summary: Add CDN to Jira Data Center Quick Start Templates

fields.description:
Hi,

I'm trying to deploy a Bitbucket Data Center Environment using the AWS Quickstart to run performance tests for my BB app.

I want to run Bitbucket without code indexing as the test environment is huge and indexing is not required for my app. During this setup, I found that setting additional properties in the shared bitbucket.properties file is overwritten when new nodes are added to the cluster.

Adding additional properties using the BitbucketProperties parameter in the Quickstart seemed to be ignored, or at least aren't applied. 

Ideally, the added properties are added to the generated properties file so I can have the best of both worlds ;)  Also not looking forward to forking all repositories, etc for this 'simple' customization.
fields.summary: BitbucketProperties are overwritten by Ansible deployment

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

As per the summary, after deploying any version of Jira from an official docker image, Tomcat will log the following false positive error on startup:
{noformat} "Unable to create directory for deployment: [$JIRA_INSTALL/conf/Catalina/localhost" false positive error{noformat} in catalina.[timestamp] file
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Deploy any version of Jira from an official docker image
 # Start the container

h3. Expected Results
# Jira should start successfully and should NOT log the above error

h3. Actual Results

# Jira starts successfully but logs the error which can be very confusing and misleading to customers, especially if other issues are present. For example, if there's a misconfiguration in server.xml, it may look like the permissions are set incorrectly on the $JIRA_INSTALL folder

The below exception is thrown in the xxxxxxx.log file:
{noformat}
"Unable to create directory for deployment:  [$JIRA_INSTALL/conf/Catalina/localhost" false positive error
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

Create the directory manually inside the container and grant the Jira's account full access to the directory:

{noformat}
mkdir -p $JIRA_ISNTALL/conf/Catalina/localhost
sudo chown -R jira:jira $JIRA_INSTALL/conf/Catalina/localhost
{noformat}
fields.summary: Jira deployed from official docker images logs "Unable to create directory for deployment: [$JIRA_INSTALL/conf/Catalina/localhost" false positive error out of the box

Jira deployed from an official docker image does not create catalina.out file in $JIRA_INST/logs folder

catalina.out file should be present in the $JIRA_INST/logs/ directory

catalina.out file is not there

no workaround known yet

fields.description:
Current version of Cloud formation template uses AWS Elasticsearch version that supports only request signing as authentication without providing basic auth or any other security features.

It would be great to implement support for Fine-grained controls for AWS Elasticsearch:

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
According to [Bitbucket Server/DC supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/supported-platforms-776640981.html] only one version of Elasticsearch is supported:
{quote}
Elasticsearch 6.4 is supported with AWS.
{quote}
While in [publicly available Cloud Formation template|https://github.com/aws-quickstart/quickstart-atlassian-bitbucket/blob/main/templates/quickstart-bitbucket-dc-with-vpc.template.yaml] the choice is only between: 2.7 and 5.5 neither of which is supported by the recent Bitbucket releases.
{code}
      ElasticsearchVersion: !If [ShouldUseES23, "2.3", "5.5"]
{code}


h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Deploy https://github.com/aws-quickstart/quickstart-atlassian-bitbucket/blob/main/templates/quickstart-bitbucket-dc-with-vpc.template.yaml
 # In AWS console navigate Services -> Elasticsearch and find your cluster.

h3. Expected Results
	
Elasticsearch version column is showing 6.4

h3. Actual Results
Elasticsearch version column is showing 5.5

h3. Workaround
 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: AWS Elasticsearch version in Cloud Formation template is not supported according to Supported platforms

fields.description:
Currently, the Jira Docker image entry point will generate Jira's {{cluster.properties}} if, and only if, the file does not already exist. This file is generated using the environment variables passed in to the container.

This gives us a major problem running Jira DC in Kubernetes, however. We use the pod IP address to populate the {{EHCACHE_LISTENER_HOSTNAME}} env var, which in turn is used to populate {{cluster.properties}}. If the pod is restarted, the IP address may change, so the env var will change, but {{cluster.properties}} will not be updated (since it already exists). The Jira node then starts up with the wrong information about its IP address, and clustering won't work.

The fix should be simple - regenerate {{cluster.properties}} every time the container starts, regardless of whether or not there is an existing file there or not.

Obviously, this will change existing behaviour, and customers may be relying on the ability to manually modify {{cluster.properties}} without fear of having their changes overwritten.

So my suggestion would be to add (yet another) environment variable which defines whether or not {{cluster.properties}} gets overwritten by the container entrypoint script. In Kubernetes, we could set the to {{true}}, but by default it would be {{false}}.

One could take this further, and say that this new env var would cause *all* of the generated config files to be regenerated, not just {{cluster.properties}}, but I don't have a strong opinion on that.
fields.summary: Regenerate Jira cluster.properties on every startup

fields.description: The [Jira Data Center Migration tool|#M2993] on AWS is a great tool for customers migrating from Jira Server to Datacenter on AWS. But it would be great if this tool also supports Azure.
fields.summary: Jira Data Center Migration App support for Azure

fields.description:
*Why:*
* Customers often need to incorporate additional library and atlassian-plugin JAR files when they run the products (whether via Docker or otherwise). A common example is to add JDBC driver libraries that cannot be shipped with the products for license reasons.
* This is currently difficult to do with our Docker images. You need to start the container with a persistent volume mount, copy the new JAR file(s) into the volume, then restart the container.
* It's also awkward to handle with Kubernetes, requiring the fiddling use of {{subPath}} volume mounts.

*What*:
* Add support for new environment variables in the Docker images which specify a volume mount location in the container which contains additional lib/plugin JAR files.
* During first container startup, copy the contents of these mounts into the appropriate place for library or plugin JARs.
fields.summary: Allow library/plugin injection via volumes

fields.description:
Currently, our Docker images will always launch the JVM in the container using {{Xmx}} and {{Xms}} flags, with a default value if the user doesn't not specify the appropriate env vars.

However, this doesn't give the JVM any chance to make an informed decision on its own, using the container's cgroups memory allocation. Since Java10, The JVM will auto-detect the cgroups allocation and allocate max heap accordingly - *unless* you override that with Xmx and Xms.

My suggestion is to provide a new environment variable, {{JVM_AUTO_MEMORY}} for example, which will omit the {{-Xmx}} and {{-Xms}} command line arguments to the JVM, and let the JVM pick its own value based on the container's constraints. Ideally, this would be the default behaviour, but we need to support the existing Xmx and Xms defaults.

For extra points, add another env var to support the {{-XX:MaxRAMPercentage}} flag, which overrides how much of the container's available memory will be allocated to the heap (it seems to default to 50%).

The result of this change would be to manage the JVM's memory sizing via container restrictions, rather than specifying it in the JVM. This is particularly compelling for Kubernetes environments, where admins want to allocate resources to the pods' containers, and have the JVM honour that, without having to dive down into Xmx and Xms configuration.
fields.summary: Provide "auto heap size" option for docker images under Java11
Docker documentation should include system properties

fields.description:
Confluence is configured to use a custom log4j appender which, shortly after startup, redirects all application logs to a file in the Confluence home directory.

This makes perfect sense when you're running Confluence manually via a shell script, but when running in a containerised environment, it's problematic. The logs become effectively invisible to the container management tools, which are expecting logs to be delivered to stdout, and it fills up the container filesystem.

The docker image could specify a system property which tells Confluence not to do this, and instead to continue to send logs to stdout.
fields.summary: Stop sending application logs to file

fields.description: As a developer or enthusiast I might want to get the latest EAP release from Docker Hub. Right now I need to know the exact build/eap/beta/milestone release tag to pull that version. I should be able to use a generic `eap` tag to pull the latest EAP release for any product that publishes EAP's.
fields.summary: Generic `eap` tag for latest EAP docker releases

fields.description:
The docker images for Confluence should be able to pick up the license as injected into the docker image. 

This license would be detected by the docker container entry point, and used to pre-populate the application's config file, in a similar manner that is used to populate the database and cluster properties.

This would allow the license entry screen of the setup wizards to be skipped.
fields.summary: Allow injection of license file into Confluence docker image

fields.description:
One of the setup options for Confluence Data Center is to run a Synchrony cluster separately from the Confluence cluster, rather than allowing the Confluence nodes to spawn and manage their own Synchrony processes.

This is documented [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/set-up-a-synchrony-cluster-for-confluence-data-center-958779073.html]. It's pretty clunky, and requires the user to copy the synchrony JAR file out of the Confluence distro and run it themselves.

In a Docker deployment, this entails specifyng a custom entrypoint when the container is created. Again, this is clunky.

It woud be great if Atlassian could provide Docker images that just contained Synchrony, allowing much easier deployment of dedicated Synchrony clusters. These would need to versioned independently from Conflence, but some sort of version compatibility matrix wuld be needed. 

As well as making Synchrony deployment easier, it would remove the need to download the full monster docker image just to run Synchrony (which is relatively tiny)

Alternatively, perhaps an another entrypoint script could be included in the Confluence images, to be invoked when you just wanted to run a Synchrony container.
fields.summary: Provide docker image for Synchrony

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

After the Confluence docker container has started, there is a {{__pycache__}} directory left in {{/var/atlassian/application-data/confluence}}.

This is an artifact of the container entrypoint script, and nothing to do with Confluence itself, and so shouldn't be in there.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Start a Confluence docker container

h3. Expected Results

Only files created by Confluence should be in {{/var/atlassian/application-data/confluence}}
h3. Actual Results

A {{\_\_pycache\_\_}} directory is found in {{/var/atlassian/application-data/confluence}}, and is owned by {{root}}.
h3. Workaround

Run the Docker container with {{PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE=1}} set in the environment.
fields.summary: Docker container entrypoint leaves _pycache__ in Confluence home directory

fields.description:
Issue:

customers are using other database than our recommandation, PostgreSQL. when they migrate to Data Center, it's a big risk and blocker for them to migration to PostgreSQL.

 

Solution: 

Provide a solution to support migrating to DC using customer existing database schemas other than PostgreSQL.
fields.summary: Support using non-PostgreSQL database when migrating to DC

the first release of The [Jira Data Center Migration tool|[https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Jira-articles/Introducing-the-Jira-Data-Center-Migration-App/ba-p/1430029#M2993]] only support standard Quick Start template, however many customer has their own customised template for production.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

h3. Environment
* [Bitbucket QuickStart|https://aws.amazon.com/quickstart/architecture/bitbucket/]
* Bitbucket DC 6.10.5

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Created and deploy new Bitbucket DC ver6.10.5 using the CloudFormation template.
# Verify the instance is up and running with one node.
# Increase the node count from one to three as guided in [Scaling up and down|https://confluence.atlassian.com/enterprise/administering-bitbucket-data-center-in-aws-970267024.html#AdministeringBitbucketDataCenterinAWS-scalingupanddownScalingupanddown]
# Validate the node count increase. {{Bitbucket Administration >> Clustering}}.
# Reduce the node from three to two.

h3. Expected Result
The scale-down reduces the node count as required.

h3. Actual result
The scale-down failed and unable to reduce the node count. The following is seen in the Stack:
 !AWS-CF-BBDC6105-Scale-Down-01.png|thumbnail! 
 !AWS-CF-BBDC6105-Scale-Down-02.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Scaling down node for Bitbucket DC 6.10.5 AWS CloudFormation runs into error

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
The Cloudformation currently default storage type - gp2. Preference of either *io1* or *gp2*(general or ssd) would allow the Sys. Admin to choose to have better disk performance for DC instances.

It would be great to see the option is given to select the node storage type during the CloudFormation template phase.
fields.summary: Defining the DC node storage type during the CloudFormation template phase

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
The Cloudformation currently default to set the node disk size to 8GB. The log directory *Bitbucket_Home/log* is stored in the node. The logs size increases drastically causing performance issue with the nodes. [Log rotation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserverkb/configure-bitbucket-server-logging-779171678.html] which able to compress and archive log files is a temporary fix.

It would be great to see the option is given to increase the node disk size during the CloudFormation template phase.

h4. Suggestion
Suggestion from the customer, similar to the [additional storage for your repository data|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/adding-additional-storage-for-your-repository-data-966065964.html] feature, having an option to add a secondary ELB to store the log, cache and temp files.
fields.summary: Defining the DC node disk size during the CloudFormation template phase

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Updating an AWS instance(Cloudformation) to a new version or deploying the instance to a new AMI would ignore the custom script function in the DC environment. The DC System Administrator had to manually copy over the script(and build it) in the new deployment. The custom script expected to monitor the nodes and perform cronjobs in nodes(i.e: removing logs - the node size limited to 8GB)

It is expected that the custom scripts have a default directory in *Bitbucket_Home*(i.e: /media/atl/bitbucket/shared/node_scripts). The nodes are able to access and copy the custom script from the mentioned directory and automate/run the script in each node's environments.
fields.summary: Custom script to be copied from one deployment to another deployment

fields.description:
Copied from https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/dc-deployments-automation/issues/2/aws_bitbucket_dc_node-yml-not-passing-full
h3. Issue Summary

The line:

- "Environment=JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS=\{{ atl_jvm_opts }}"

Does not appear to pass all JVM options, it's possible my syntax is incorrect, but in my testing only the first arg is passed.

What works for me is single quoting the full assignment, such as:

- "Environment='JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS=\{{ atl_jvm_opts }}'"

‌

 

 
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Fill atl_jvm_opts variable when starting the Ansible role
h3. Expected Results

Which would then get passed to systemd as:

Environment=JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS=-Dhttp.proxyHost=10.15.112.40 -Dhttp.proxyPort=3128 -Dhttps.proxyHost=10.15.112.40 -Dhttps.proxyPort=3128 -Dhttp.nonProxyHosts=localhost|169.254.169.254
h3. Actual Results

In my case, I was passing this to JvmSupportOpts, that later is written to /etc/atl:

"-Dhttp.proxyHost=10.15.112.40 -Dhttp.proxyPort=3128 -Dhttps.proxyHost=10.15.112.40 -Dhttps.proxyPort=3128 -Dhttp.nonProxyHosts=localhost|169.254.169.254"
h3. Workaround

Override the value in the file manually.
fields.summary: aws_bitbucket_dc_node yml not passing full environment for atl_jvm_opts

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, if you have a YAML configuration within docker to create a Jira instance and have MySQL and the following settings.
{code:java}
ALT_DB_VALIDATIONQUERYTIMEOUT: 3
{code}
h3. Suggested Solution

Ideally, all the configuration within the YAML should be transferred over to the dbconfig.xml where they match up like the validation-query-timeout.
h3. Sample YAML
{code:java}
- name: (Jira_podName)        
image: atlassian/jira-software:#.#.#-jdk11        
env:      
- name: ATL_JDBC_USER
value: (jira_username)
- name: ATL_JDBC_PASSWORD
value: (password)
- name: ATL_DB_DRIVER          
value: com.mysql.jdbc.Driver        
- name: ATL_DB_TYPE          
value: mysql        
- name: ATL_DB_MINEVICTABLEIDLETIMEMILLIS         
value: "60000"        
- name: ATL_DB_VALIDATIONQUERYTIMEOUT          
value: "3"
{code}
fields.summary: YAML configuration should be used when creating the dbconfig.xml.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
The {{${JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS}}} argument is used to inject Java environment variables into the Confluence Docker container

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Create a docker container using the following argument
{code:title=Docker Argument}
-e JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS=-XX:+PrintGCDetails
{code}

h3. Expected Results
The {{-XX:+PrintGCDetails}} value should be configured

h3. Actual Results
The {{-XX:+PrintGCDetails}} value is not configured

The following appears in the startup log
{code:title=Startup Log}
29-May-2020 06:33:13.145 INFO [main] org.apache.catalina.startup.VersionLoggerListener.log Command line argument: -XX:+PrintGCDetails
...
29-May-2020 06:33:13.150 INFO [main] org.apache.catalina.startup.VersionLoggerListener.log Command line argument: -XX:-PrintGCDetails
{code}
This causes the default configuration of {{-XX:-PrintGCDetails}} to override {{-XX:+PrintGCDetails}} defined in {{${JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS}}}.

This is caused by incorrect ordering of variables in the {{<confluence-install>/bin/setenv.sh}} file.

h3. Workaround
Modify the {{/opt/atlassian/confluence/bin/setenv.sh}} file to reflect the following
{code:title=setenv.sh}
# Set the JVM arguments used to start Confluence.
# For a description of the vm options of jdk 8, see:
# http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/tech/vmoptions-jsp-140102.html
# For a description of the vm options of jdk 11, see:
# https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/tools/java.html
CATALINA_OPTS="-XX:+IgnoreUnrecognizedVMOptions ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-XX:-PrintGCDetails -XX:+PrintGCDateStamps -XX:-PrintTenuringDistribution ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-Xlog:gc+age=debug:file=$LOGBASEABS/logs/gc-`date +%F_%H-%M-%S`.log::filecount=5,filesize=2M ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-Xloggc:$LOGBASEABS/logs/gc-`date +%F_%H-%M-%S`.log -XX:+UseGCLogFileRotation -XX:NumberOfGCLogFiles=5 -XX:GCLogFileSize=2M ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-XX:G1ReservePercent=20 ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-Djava.awt.headless=true ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-Datlassian.plugins.enable.wait=300 ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-Xms${JVM_MINIMUM_MEMORY:=1024m} -Xmx${JVM_MAXIMUM_MEMORY:=1024m} -Dconfluence.home=${CONFLUENCE_HOME} -XX:+UseG1GC ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-Dsynchrony.enable.xhr.fallback=true ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-Dorg.apache.tomcat.websocket.DEFAULT_BUFFER_SIZE=32768 ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-Djava.locale.providers=JRE,SPI,CLDR ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="${START_CONFLUENCE_JAVA_OPTS} ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-Dconfluence.context.path=${CONFLUENCE_CONTEXT_PATH} ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-Djdk.tls.server.protocols=TLSv1.1,TLSv1.2 -Djdk.tls.client.protocols=TLSv1.1,TLSv1.2 ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="-XX:ReservedCodeCacheSize=${JVM_RESERVED_CODE_CACHE_SIZE:=256m} -XX:+UseCodeCacheFlushing ${CATALINA_OPTS}"
CATALINA_OPTS="${CATALINA_OPTS} ${JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS}"
{code}
This removes the {{${JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS}}} from a line in the middle of the text block, and appends {{CATALINA_OPTS="${CATALINA_OPTS} ${JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS}"}} to the bottom.
fields.summary: ${JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS} is incorrectly overridden by default configuration in Confluence containers

fields.description:
Some Customers running Jira in a Docker container and would like to use the *--read-only* flag provided by Docker but there is *no support nor documents provided* for this flag as it's *not officially supported*.

I would like Atlassian to provide a Test & Documents for Docker's *--read-only* flag for Jira.

h3. Benefits

Checking the Docker Doc for [Read-only|https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/run/#mount-volume--v---read-only] command, it mentions
{quote} Volumes can be used in combination with --read-only to control where a container writes files. The --read-only flag mounts the container’s root filesystem as read only prohibiting writes to locations other than the specified volumes for the container.
{quote}

Which is sometimes needed to provide a more secure environment as a part of STIG, it is to use read-only flag to prevents any writes to the container's root filesystem at container runtime and enforces the principle of immutable infrastructure.

*Further details*

The container's root filesystem should be treated as a 'golden image' by using Docker run's --read-only option. This prevents any writes to the container's root filesystem at container runtime and enforces the principle of immutable infrastructure.

Enabling this option forces containers at runtime to explicitly define their data writing strategy to persist or not persist their data. This also reduces security attack vectors since the container instance's filesystem cannot be tampered with or written to unless it has explicit read-write permissions on its filesystem folder and directories.

Enabling --read-only at container runtime may break some container OS packages if a data writing strategy is not defined. Define what the container's data should and should not persist at runtime to determine which recommendation procedure to utilize.
Example:
* Enable use --tmpfs for temporary file writes to /tmp
* Use Docker shared data volumes for persistent data writes

By default, a container will have its root filesystem writable allowing all container processes to write files owned by the container's runtime user.

{panel:title=Note}
Here is a rough estimate on how the script should look like: 

(!) *This is an untested Script, kindly test on your own risk*

{code:java}
docker run -d \
    --name jiratest \
    --read-only \
    -v ~/Docker/jiratest/home:/var/atlassian/application-data/jira \
    -v ~/Docker/jiratest/temp:/opt/atlassian/jira/temp \
    -v ~/Docker/jiratest/logs:/opt/atlassian/jira/logs \
    -v ~/Docker/jiratest/work:/opt/atlassian/jira/work \
    -p 8080:8080 \
    atlassian/jira-software
{code}

I would suggest you try testing the above script in your testing environment and see if that helps you start Jira.
{panel}
fields.summary: Provide a Test & Documents for Docker's "--read-only" flag for Jira

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The Confluence Docker page in [https://hub.docker.com/r/atlassian/confluence-server/] indicates that users should be copying the downloaded mysql or oracle jdbc drivers into the
{code:borderStyle=solid}
/opt/atlassian/confluence/lib
{code}
directory.
 
{quote} docker cp mysql-connector-java.x.y.z.jar confluence:/opt/atlassian/confluence/lib
docker restart confluence
{quote}
 
However this appears to be incorrect of Confluence.

 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Follow steps in https://hub.docker.com/r/atlassian/confluence-server/ for copying mysql jdbc jar file

h3. Expected Results
Following the steps in the guide should let you connect to such a database.

h3. Actual Results
Confluence still can't connect to that database when following documented steps

h3. Workaround
copying these files to the directory
{code:borderStyle=solid}
/opt/atlassian/confluence/confluence/WEB_INF/lib 
{code} will work.

fields.description:
h2. Summary

We are using your official quickstart template.

Version here:

https://github.com/aws-quickstart/quickstart-atlassian-confluence/blob/dc4602861cd24b5be308c5be83e60669affcd5d7/templates/quickstart-confluence-master.template.yaml

We have changed nothing in the template.

So we deployed our Confluence-DC with the Quickstart-Template on AWS.

It works well until we deploy new nodes.

 

Every time the saved licencedetails get lost on the fresh deployed node and we have to apply it manually. Especially if we wish to use the autoscale group thats pretty frustrating and reduces the benefits from it.

Didn’t find anything about this yet. Is this an known Issue? Any help there for this?

 
h2. Problem description  

1. Install the VPC-Stack with your template

1. Just install the 7.3.5 Version (happened too with any installed versions before) with the linked template in the VPC.

2. Then apply an license in the admin panel. (General configuration => License Details)

3. Increasing the EC2 node instances in the Cloudformation Stack

 
h2. Expected behaviour

New nodes have a license
h2. Actual behaviour

The existing node keeps its license unchanged.

While the addition / new nodes wont have any licence applied.

 
h2. Notes / Addendum 

On a separate note - I tried to create this bug report in the linked bitbucket repo but it seems only for internal usage. It would be less confusing if you make it private. Or at least disallow customers to create bugreports there.

 

https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/atlassian-aws-deployment/issues/47/confluence-quickstart-template-licence
fields.summary: Confluence Quickstart Template Licence

fields.description:
Currently we do not have the j2 template for seraph-config.xml. Confluence image on the other hand, has it. Due to this, it is not possible to include a modified seraph-config.xml via j2 templates alongside other templates as well under {{$JIRA_INSTALL_DIR/etc}}.

Overwriting the j2 template is the official, supported way to supply a custom file to an image.

h3. Workaround

Create a custom Docker build from the base https://hub.docker.com/r/atlassian/jira-software image, and COPY the modified seraph-config.xml to {{opt/atlassian/jira/atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/classes/seraph-config.xml}}.

Example Dockerfile:
{code:none}
FROM atlassian/jira-software:8.8.0
COPY seraph-config.xml.modified /opt/atlassian/jira/atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/classes/seraph-config.xml
{code}
fields.summary: Add a j2 template for seraph-config.xml for Jira Docker image

h3. Issue Summary
Starting Confluence DC as Docker or ECS in AWS environment with clustering mode set to AWS will fail with error unable to find EC2 instance.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an EC2 instance in AWS.
 # Follow the [Confluence Docker Datacenter|https://hub.docker.com/r/atlassian/confluence-server/] documentation to run confluence.
# During the configuration phase use the AWS as a "ATL_CLUSTER_TYPE".

h3. Expected Results
The instance will start without any problems.

h3. Actual Results
The instance will start with an incorrect cluster and with the error.
Starting another node will cause cluster panic as nodes can not talk to each other 
(cluster failed).

The below exception is thrown in the Atlassian-confluence.log file:
{noformat}
Datacenter AWS hazelcast ... No EC2 instances found!
{noformat}

h3. Workaround
Use TCP_ip clusterin mode, or use the Cloud formation template if you need to dynamically add instances.
fields.summary: Starting Confluence DC as a docker or ECS in AWS environment with clustering mode set to AWS will fail.

fields.description:
We tried to create a report of our issues with Xporter. We had issues and contacted Xporter support. They helped us triage the issue. The issue was that the Java version used in the Jira Docker images does not support NashornScriptEngine or JavascriptEngine. Our issue is solved when we manually update the Java version in the container, but we do not want to use such a heavily modified image.
The issue appears with JDK version 8u222 which is used in the official image. We updated to 8u232 which resolved our problem.

Can the official image be updated, or can an additional tag be created which supports the classes NashornScriptEngine or JavascriptEngine?
fields.summary: Docker image does not support NashornScriptEngine/JavascriptEngine

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Confluence fails to communicate with Synchrony when the instances are generated on AWS by using CloudFormation Quick Start template with "Permitted IP range (CidrBlock)" setting. 
https://aws.amazon.com/quickstart/architecture/confluence/

h3. Environment
AWS 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Proceed deployment step following Quick Start page above
 # Set your client computer's public IP address for "Permitted IP range (CidrBlock)". e.g. {{123.123.123.123/32}}
 # Visit the URL of deployed Confluence instance
 # Enable Synchrony from Confluence GUI

h3. Expected Results
Synchrony starts up.

h3. Actual Results
Confluence cannot communicate with Synchrony
 !Screen Shot 2019-07-31 at 12.58.00.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Notes
Apparently this is because Confluence is trying to talk to Synchrony with following route.
Confluence -> NAT Gateway in VPC -> Application Load Balancer -> Synchrony

In this case Application Load Balancer has security group configuration that allows only client computer's public IP due to the "Permitted IP range (CidrBlock)", therefore the route above is shut off.

h3. Workaround

Check public IP addresses configured for NAT Gateway for your VPC, and add records to Security Group of Application Load Balancer to allow them.
fields.summary: Confluence cannot communicate with Synchrony if "Permitted IP range (CidrBlock)" is set on CloudFormation Quick Start template

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Confluence docker was not able to start up by following the database configuration in https://hub.docker.com/r/atlassian/confluence-server. Keep getting *Setup Database Failed* error from UI.

h3. Environment
* Confluence docker

h3. Steps to Reproduce
{code}
docker run --name="confluence" -d \
-p 8090:8090 \
-p 8091:8091 \
-v ~/docker-home/confluence-home:/var/atlassian/application-data/confluence \
-e ATL_JDBC_URL=jdbc:postgresql://postgres.testnet:5432/confluence \
-e ATL_JDBC_USER=username \
-e ATL_JDBC_PASSWORD= \
-e ATL_DB_TYPE=postgresql \
--network testnet \
atlassian/confluence-server:latest
{code}

h3. Expected Results
Avoiding the need to do the database setup through the UI.

h3. Actual Results
!Screen Shot 2019-10-15 at 3.26.27 pm.png|width=500! 

h3. Note
Here is the template of confluence.cfg.xml in /etc/atlassian/etc/confluence.cfg.xml.j2
{code}
{% if atl_jdbc_url is defined %}
      {% set databases =  {
           "mysql": ["com.mysql.jdbc.Driver", "MySQLDialect"],
           "postgresql": ["org.postgresql.Driver", "PostgreSQLDialect"],
           "mssql": ["com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver", "SQLServerDialect"],
           "oracle12c": ["oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver", "OracleDialect"]
          } %}
      <property name="confluence.database.choice">{{ atl_db_type }}</property>

      <property name="hibernate.connection.url">{{ atl_jdbc_url }}</property>
      <property name="hibernate.connection.username">{{ atl_jdbc_user }}</property>
      <property name="hibernate.connection.password">{{ atl_jdbc_password }}</property>
      <property name="hibernate.connection.driver_class">{{ databases[atl_db_type][0] }}</property>
      <property name="hibernate.dialect">com.atlassian.confluence.impl.hibernate.dialect.{{ databases[atl_db_type][1] }}</property>
{code}

h3. Workaround
* A password must be specified using the {{ATL_JDBC_PASSWORD}} environment variable
fields.summary: Confluence docker database configuration not working

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When testing connection for an OAuth 2.0 integration fails, no error details are displayed in application logs.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Add an invalid OAuth 2.0 configuration
 # On the list of configurations, click 'Test connection'
 # Await error: 'The connection has failed. Check the application logs for details.'

h3. Expected Results

Application logs contain details about the error.
h3. Actual Results

Application logs have no additional information about the error.
h3. Workaround

The error details are sent back from the server in REST response. Use browser's dev tools to preview network communication, and the error can be extracted from response body:
{code:java}
{
  "success": false,
  "error": "<details>"
}
{code}
fields.summary: Testing connection to invalid OAuth 2.0 integration produces no logs

h3. Problem statement
Sometimes customers would like to migrate only current issues and leave out any closed issues for example. At the moment, JCMA migrates all issues within a project with no exception.

h3. Suggested solution
Allow the migration of certain issues from projects based on status or JQL.
fields.summary: Support partial project migration

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When doing Jira site import, mostly from on-premises, you may see a failure during the last stage of the import, when activating Jira.

It seems this may be caused by duplicated users (same username, email address, etc).

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a backup of Jira Server
# Have at least one user that is duplicated (internal/external directory).
# Perform a Jira site import on Cloud.

h3. Expected Results

The Jira site import would report the offending (duplicated) account during the validation process.

h3. Actual Results

The Jira site import fails with an exception:

 !Screenshot 2021-12-30 093219.png|thumbnail! 

The below exception is thrown in the xxxxxxx.log file:
{noformat}
com.querydsl.core.QueryException: Caught PSQLException for select 1
from "public"."cwd_user" "CWD_USER"
where "CWD_USER"."id" in (?, ?, ?)
...
Caused by: org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: ERROR: canceling statement due to statement timeout
  Where: while locking tuple (0,2) in relation "cwd_user"
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

Try to follow the steps in both documentations:

- [Resolve user and groups synchronization error|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloudkb/resolve-user-and-groups-synchronization-error-1036061499.html]

- [Jira Pre-migration Checklist|https://support.atlassian.com/migration/docs/jira-pre-migration-checklist]
fields.summary: Site import fails in the last task while activating Jira

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
If a customer tries to run a Confluence site import using a Confluence server space backup, they receive a misleading error message:
{code}This file was exported from Confluence Server. We can only import files exported from Confluence Cloud in the site importer. To migrate a site from Confluence Server to Confluence Cloud, use the Confluence Cloud Migration Assistant. If you need additional help, please raise a support request.{code}
Instead, it should tell them to run a Space import instead of the site import.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Generate a space backup from Confluence server/DC
 # Try to perform a site import in Cloud using this backup

h3. Expected Results
Error message saying to use the space import, since it is a space backup

h3. Actual Results
The following error message is thrown:
 !Screen Shot 2021-12-28 at 17.37.58.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
Check the file exportDescriptor.properties in the zip file, if you find the entry *exportType=space*, use the space import instead of site import.
fields.summary: Misleading error when trying to perform a Confluence site import using a server space backup

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Tickets that do not contain the source/destination Status ID on the history tab will cause the "My requests" (customer portal) page to not retrieve issues and be not interactive. This is caused by JCMA not importing the status ID of statuses deleted on the Server instance.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# On a server instance, create a new project.
# Create a new issue and transition it through a few different statuses. (Example *To do* > *Pending* > *In Progress* > *Done*)
# Remove one of those statuses from the associated workflow and delete it. 
# Note that even after deleting the status, the issue history tab will keep a record of the Status name and ID.
# Migrate the project to Cloud via JCMA.

h3. Expected Results

- All the issues, statuses, and references are preserved.

h3. Actual Results

The id of the status deleted on the Server instance will not exist on the issue history.

 !image-2021-12-24-16-22-06-701.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Notes

This bug will cause several side effects on JSM portal, such as:

- Affected issues will prevent the JSM Customer portal from loading tickets on the "Requests" page.
- Affected issues will not load on the portal.
- The "Manage columns" feature of the portal will break.


h3.Workaround

No workaround at the moment.
